text:
Well, y'all... I got good news, and I got
bad news.
I'll start with the bad news.

A new study from NASA and the University of
California-Irvine, has found that a large

part of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is now
melting irreversibly.

Some of you have written us asking what that
means, and what exactly is going on down there,
so let's take a look.

The part of the continent they're talking
about is called the Amundsen Sea sector, which

contains enough frozen fresh water to raise
the global sea level by 1.2 meters.

This water is locked up in glaciers, or huge
moving masses of ice, and the glaciers in

this sector are melting faster than scientists
expected. Satellite data show that Antarctica

is now losing 159 metric gigatons of ice every
year -- the vast majority of it, about 134
gigatons, in West Antarctica.

And according to glaciologists, the Amundsen
sector has passed what they call "the point

of no return" which means that nothing can
stop it from melting completely.

They know this because glacial melt is basically
caught in a positive feedback loop.

See, the Antarctic Ice Sheet doesn't float
-- it sits on land. This is good if you're

one of the billion or so people living in
low-lying coastal areas somewhere on Earth,

because, in Antarctica, the land is colder
than the water.

But those glaciers are always moving, and
they're moving down toward the ocean.

The place where a glacier loses contact with
solid land and starts floating on the water
is called its grounding line.

And the grounding line isn't always above
sea level. The Amundsen Sea sector typically

rests on the bedrock of the ocean floor. In
some areas, that's two and a half kilometers
down!

But the new study has found that six of the
major glaciers in West Antarctica are now

floating above where they used to be grounded
on the seafloor, which means they've thinned,
and their grounding lines have moved inland.

And this just accelerates the melting, because
nearly all glacial melt occurs on the underside

of glaciers when they're floating, not on
land.

And as the glacier gets lighter and thinner,
it starts moving even faster into ocean ... and

you can probably see now why the whole thing
has become unstoppable.

Because the grounding lines beneath these
six glaciers are under hundreds of meters

of ice, it's hard to tell exactly how fast
this is happening. But it is, definitely,

happening. And in the Amundsen Sea sector,
it's not going to stop happening until there
is no more Amundsen Sea sector.

Which glaciologists say could happen in the
next 200 to 900 years.

We're problem solvers, right? Humans are almost
as good at solving problems as we are at creating
them.

Which brings us to the good news: Nesta, an
innovation charity based in the UK, has launched

the Longitude Prize, to award 10 million pounds
to whoever solves one of the biggest scientific
problems of our time.

It takes its name from the reward offered
by the British Government back in 1714 to

any scientist who could solve one of the most
vexing puzzles of their day: how a ship at

sea could determine its exact location by
measuring its longitude.

The modern Longitude Prize is similar, only
instead of figuring out how to orient ships,

it's getting people to make other people's
lives better. And instead of a million dollars,
it's a lot more than that.

There are six candidates for this year's Longitude
Prize problems, only one of which will be

chosen, and if you live in the United Kingdom,
you can vote on which problem you want science
to solve!

One candidate, for example, is green air travel:
Since the CO2 emitted by airplanes has twice

the greenhouse effect as ground-based sources,
how can we fly without damaging the environment?

There's also a challenge to revolutionize
food, and develop an agricultural innovation

that would make nutritious food more accessible
while keeping it cheap and sustainable.

Then there are Antibiotics, which we here
at SciShow have talked about recently. With

antibiotic resistance on the rise, this prize
would go toward a quick, accurate test for

infections that doctors could use to make
sure they're giving the right antibiotic at
the right time.

Nearly 1 in 50 people live with some form
of paralysis, meanwhile, mostly because of

spinal injury, multiple sclerosis, or stroke.
If this category wins, the money would reward

new technology that could restore as much
freedom of movement as possible in people
with paralysis.

There's also a chance to have a run at a problem
that has stymied scientists for centuries:

finding an inexpensive way to desalinate water,
so people can have fresh water without tapping

into the limited amount circulating around
the planet.

And finally: One in three seniors will develop
some form of dementia, so the sixth challenge

would reward treatments or technology that
could allow patients to live independently
for longer.

These are all, of course, worthy questions,
and you get to help find an answer. Voting

will remain open until June 25th, when the
winner will be announced, so if you live in

UK, vote for the kind of suck that you want
science to decrease.

Thanks for watching SciShow News! If you want
to keep learning more about the world and

helping to make it more awesome, just go to
subbable.com and become a contributing member.
Don't forget to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe!
